Summary : This bar chart presents the monthly energy consumption profile in kilowatt-hours (KWH) for two categories, "onpk" and "offpk", across the months of the year (D to N). bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "Energy Profile". • Y-axis: "KWH" (kilowatt-hours), with tick marks at 0, 10000, 20000, 30000, 40000. • X-axis: Months labeled as D, J, F, M, A, M, J, J, A, S, O, N, D (presumably December to November, with D repeated at both ends). Data Points : • Series "onpk" (lighter bars): Monthly KWH values, generally lower than "offpk" for each month. • Series "offpk" (darker bars): Monthly KWH values, generally higher than "onpk", with a pronounced spike in September. • Both series are present for each month. Design Encodings : • "onpk" and "offpk" are distinguished by different bar fill patterns (as indicated in the legend). • Grouped bar format for each month. • No error bars or additional statistical annotations. Distribution & Trends : • Most months show "offpk" consumption exceeding "onpk". • September ("S") displays a dramatic spike in "offpk" KWH, reaching the highest value on the chart (over 35000 KWH). • Other months show moderate variation, with both series generally between 5000 and 20000 KWH. • October ("O") also shows a secondary peak in "offpk". Analysis : • "offpk" energy usage is consistently higher than "onpk" throughout the year. • There is a significant anomaly in September, where "offpk" consumption surges far above all other months. • October also shows elevated "offpk" usage, but not as extreme as September. • The rest of the year displays relatively stable energy consumption for both categories, with minor fluctuations. Summary : This bar chart shows the monthly maximum demand history in kilowatts (KW) over a one-year period, with each month represented by its initial letter. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "Demand History". • Y-axis: "Max KW", ranging from 0 to 250 in increments of 50. • X-axis: Months, labeled by initials: D, J, F, M, A, M, J, J, A, S, O, N, D. Data Points : • Each bar represents the maximum KW demand for a given month. • The highest bar occurs in September (S), reaching just below 200 KW. • Other months generally range between approximately 75 KW and 125 KW. Design Encodings : • Bars are uniform in color and style. • No additional series, error bars, or trend lines. Distribution & Trends : • Most months show similar demand levels, except for a pronounced spike in September. • No clear upward or downward trend across the year, aside from the outlier. Analysis : • The data reveals a significant outlier in September, where demand nearly doubles compared to other months. • The rest of the year exhibits relatively stable demand, with minor fluctuations. • The September spike may indicate a seasonal or event-driven increase in demand. Summary : This bar chart shows the generation rate in cents per kilowatt-hour (KWH) for different months, with each bar representing a specific month labeled by its initial. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "Generation Rate" • Y-axis: "Cents Per KWH" with tick marks at 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20. • X-axis: Month initials: D, F, A, J, A, O, D. Data Points : • Each bar represents the generation rate for a month (D, F, A, J, A, O, D). • All bars are between 6 and 8 cents per KWH, except for the two central bars (A, J) which are slightly higher, close to 8 cents per KWH. Design Encodings : • Bars are vertical and shaded with a light fill. • No colour differentiation between bars. • No error bars or additional markers. Distribution & Trends : • Most months cluster around 6–7 cents per KWH. • Two months (A, J) show a small peak, reaching just under 8 cents per KWH. Analysis : • The generation rate is relatively stable across most months, with a minor increase in the middle months (A, J). No extreme outliers or sharp trends are visible. Meter Information

Your Supplier: NEXTERA ENERGY SERVICES CONNECTICUT Phone: (866) 410-4392 20 GREENWAY PLAZA SUITE 600 HOUSTON, TX 77046 Mail Payment To: EVERSOURCE PO BOX 56002 BOSTON MA 02205-6002 Summary : This is a simple blue line drawing of a loaf of bread, depicted with curved lines and internal scoring marks. illustration: Scene Overview : • Main subject is a stylized loaf of bread, drawn in blue ink. • The loaf is shown as an oval with three curved lines inside, representing scoring or cuts on the bread's surface. • The drawing is minimalistic, with no background or additional elements. Technical Details : • No scale bar, text, or annotations are present. • The illustration uses a single blue color for all lines. Spatial Relationships : • The loaf is oriented diagonally from lower left to upper right. • The scoring lines are parallel and evenly spaced within the loaf outline. Analysis : • The image conveys the recognizable shape and scoring pattern of a traditional loaf of bread, using simple lines for clarity and emphasis. Summary : This is a handwritten identifier or code, likely referencing a document, form, or postal address. logo / stamp / identifier: Text Content : • The text reads: "P.O. 240 262". • "P.O." is commonly an abbreviation for "Post Office" or "Purchase Order". • The numbers "240 262" follow the abbreviation, separated by a space. Style & Placement : • Handwritten in black ink. • Rounded, cursive style for "P.O.", more upright for the numbers. • No additional graphic elements, borders, or logos. • No visible date, signature, or decorative features. • No indication of physical dimensions or placement context. Analysis : • The mark serves as a simple handwritten reference code, likely for organizational or tracking purposes. No branding or additional meaning is conveyed beyond the identifier itself. Summary : This image shows a payment approval stamp and a handwritten signature, indicating authorization for a financial transaction. stamp and signature: Stamp Details : • Text: "Approved For Payment" in red ink, sans-serif font, slightly angled. • No border or date visible. • Ink colour: red. • Placement: top of the image, above the signature. Signature Details : • Handwritten, red ink, cursive style. • Name: [illegible] (cannot be confidently transcribed). • Signature is slanted upward, with large initial and terminal strokes. • No underline or flourish beyond the main strokes. Dimensions & Placement : • Stamp and signature are closely aligned, with the signature directly below the stamp text. • Both elements are oriented at a slight angle. Analysis : • The stamp and signature together indicate formal approval for payment, with the red ink enhancing visibility and authority. Please Make Checks Payable to EVERSOURCE And Return This Portion With Your Payment. Thank You.

Total Delivery Services $3,156.88 Account Number: 51418123048 Statement Date: Dec 19 2023 Billing Cycle: 9 Service Address: BERLIN EMMA WILLARD SCHOOL 1088 NORTON RD BERLIN CT 06037 __Account Messages__ Non-residential and residential non-hardship customers may be subject to a 1.00% late payment charge if the "Total Amount Due" is not received by Feb 20 2024 NET KWH PURCHASES: 38062 PURCHASES - 1647 Sales (Current Sales 1647 + Prev Carryfwd Sales 0) = 36415. New Carry Fwd Sales = 0 NET ON PEAK KWH PURCHASES: 11389 PURCHASES - 238 SALES = 11,151 NET OFF PEAK KWH PURCHASES: 26673 PURCHASES - 1409 SALES = 25,264 *The combined Public Charge represents a combination of three formally known as: "Conservation and Load Management Charge, Renewable Energy Investment Charge, and the System Benefits Charge." This charge also includes the Conservation Adjustment Mechanism approved by the Public Utilities Regulatory Authority in Docket No. 13-11-14. **Effective January 1, 2007, The Generation Services Charge (GSC) and the Bypassable Federally Mandated Congestion Charge (BFMCC) have been combined into the "GSC Charge" listed in the Supplier Services Section of your bill. The GSC reflects all of the cost of procuring energy from Eversource wholesale suppliers. The BFMCC portion of this line item is $0.0003/kWh. If you multiply the BFMCC rate by the number of kWhs on your bill, you can calculate the dollar amount associated with the BFMCC. Local Delivery Improvements: Recovers company investments that protect, strengthen or modernize the electric grid. Beginning this month, you will receive a bill credit as a result of the performance penalty assessed by the Public Utilities Regulatory Authority related to Tropical Storm Isaias. This credit is based on usage and varies by customer rate. For the typical customer using 700 kWh of electricity a month, the credit is about $1 a month and will be in effect for 12 billing cycles. See "TS Isaias Performance Penalty" on page 2 of your bill.

Summary : This bar chart presents the monthly energy consumption profile in kilowatt-hours (KWH) for two categories, "onpk" and "offpk", across the months of the year (D to N).

bar chart:
Title & Axes :
  • Title: "Energy Profile".
  • Y-axis: "KWH" (kilowatt-hours), with tick marks at 0, 10000, 20000, 30000, 40000.
  • X-axis: Months labeled as D, J, F, M, A, M, J, J, A, S, O, N, D (presumably December to November, with D repeated at both ends).

Data Points :
  • Series "onpk" (lighter bars): Monthly KWH values, generally lower than "offpk" for each month.
  • Series "offpk" (darker bars): Monthly KWH values, generally higher than "onpk", with a pronounced spike in September.
  • Both series are present for each month.

Design Encodings :
  • "onpk" and "offpk" are distinguished by different bar fill patterns (as indicated in the legend).
  • Grouped bar format for each month.
  • No error bars or additional statistical annotations.

Distribution & Trends :
  • Most months show "offpk" consumption exceeding "onpk".
  • September ("S") displays a dramatic spike in "offpk" KWH, reaching the highest value on the chart (over 35000 KWH).
  • Other months show moderate variation, with both series generally between 5000 and 20000 KWH.
  • October ("O") also shows a secondary peak in "offpk".

Analysis :
  • "offpk" energy usage is consistently higher than "onpk" throughout the year.
  • There is a significant anomaly in September, where "offpk" consumption surges far above all other months.
  • October also shows elevated "offpk" usage, but not as extreme as September.
  • The rest of the year displays relatively stable energy consumption for both categories, with minor fluctuations.

Summary : This bar chart shows the monthly maximum demand history in kilowatts (KW) over a one-year period, with each month represented by its initial letter.

bar chart:

Title & Axes :
  • Title: "Demand History".
  • Y-axis: "Max KW", ranging from 0 to 250 in increments of 50.
  • X-axis: Months, labeled by initials: D, J, F, M, A, M, J, J, A, S, O, N, D.

Data Points :
  • Each bar represents the maximum KW demand for a given month.
  • The highest bar occurs in September (S), reaching just below 200 KW.
  • Other months generally range between approximately 75 KW and 125 KW.

Design Encodings :
  • Bars are uniform in color and style.
  • No additional series, error bars, or trend lines.

Distribution & Trends :
  • Most months show similar demand levels, except for a pronounced spike in September.
  • No clear upward or downward trend across the year, aside from the outlier.

Analysis :
  • The data reveals a significant outlier in September, where demand nearly doubles compared to other months.
  • The rest of the year exhibits relatively stable demand, with minor fluctuations.
  • The September spike may indicate a seasonal or event-driven increase in demand.

Summary : This bar chart shows the generation rate in cents per kilowatt-hour (KWH) for different months, with each bar representing a specific month labeled by its initial.

bar chart:
Title & Axes :
  • Title: "Generation Rate"
  • Y-axis: "Cents Per KWH" with tick marks at 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20.
  • X-axis: Month initials: D, F, A, J, A, O, D.

Data Points :
  • Each bar represents the generation rate for a month (D, F, A, J, A, O, D).
  • All bars are between 6 and 8 cents per KWH, except for the two central bars (A, J) which are slightly higher, close to 8 cents per KWH.

Design Encodings :
  • Bars are vertical and shaded with a light fill.
  • No colour differentiation between bars.
  • No error bars or additional markers.

Distribution & Trends :
  • Most months cluster around 6–7 cents per KWH.
  • Two months (A, J) show a small peak, reaching just under 8 cents per KWH.

Analysis :
  • The generation rate is relatively stable across most months, with a minor increase in the middle months (A, J). No extreme outliers or sharp trends are visible.

__Account Messages__  
Non-residential and residential non-hardship customers may be subject to a 1.00% late payment charge if the "Total Amount Due" is not received by Feb 20 2024

NET KWH PURCHASES:  38062  PURCHASES  -  1647  Sales  (Current Sales 1647  +  Prev Carryfwd Sales 0) = 36415.  New Carry Fwd Sales = 0
NET ON PEAK KWH PURCHASES:  11389 PURCHASES  -  238 SALES  =  11,151
NET OFF PEAK KWH PURCHASES:  26673 PURCHASES  -  1409 SALES  =  25,264

*The combined Public Charge represents a combination of three formally known as: "Conservation and Load Management Charge, Renewable Energy Investment Charge, and the System Benefits Charge." This charge also includes the Conservation Adjustment Mechanism approved by the Public Utilities Regulatory Authority in Docket No. 13-11-14.
**Effective January 1, 2007, The Generation Services Charge (GSC) and the Bypassable Federally Mandated Congestion Charge (BFMCC) have been combined into the "GSC Charge" listed in the Supplier Services Section of your bill. The GSC reflects all of the cost of procuring energy from Eversource wholesale suppliers. The BFMCC portion of this line item is $0.0003/kWh. If you multiply the BFMCC rate by the number of kWhs on your bill, you can calculate the dollar amount associated with the BFMCC.
Local Delivery Improvements: Recovers company investments that protect, strengthen or modernize the electric grid.
Beginning this month, you will receive a bill credit as a result of the performance penalty assessed by the Public Utilities Regulatory Authority related to Tropical Storm Isaias. This credit is based on usage and varies by customer rate. For the typical customer using 700 kWh of electricity a month, the credit is about $1 a month and will be in effect for 12 billing cycles. See "TS Isaias Performance Penalty" on page 2 of your bill.
